Posts.Content: Thanks for the input guys. I have decided to switch to decaf coffee, not as bad as I thought it might be . Not sure about the exercises, my doc said not to, but many people have great success with them. Unfortunately my doc is away 'til May 27th, so can't ask him why he doesn't want me to do them.

Posts.Title: Suggestions? Experience?

Posts.Content: Thanks MoHawk. Right now I am 5 weeks out of surgery, 3 weeks with catheter out, and my incontinence hasn't improved at all. I do walk every day, but just started doing Kegels this week, even though my doc said no special exercises, but he's away right now and I feel like I have to do something. One thing I have noticed recently, if I sit for a while and my bladder fills, it is less likely to leak when I stand up.(I'm tempted to drink non-stop, and keep my bladder full! lol ) Anybody else experienced this? Is it a good sign?

Posts.Title: Suggestions? Experience?

Posts.Content: So. It's been 3 weeks since my surgery, and a week since I had the catheter removed. Yay! Right now I have ZERO bladder control. I was expecting something like this, but not really to this extent. My doc said give it a few weeks, no special exercises, let my body do it's work. Walk. I'm not really one to sit and wait for stuff to happen, so, my question is, what are you guys doing to lessen the impact of urinary incontinence on your daily lives? Have you changed your diet? Exercise more? Less alcohol, more alcohol? I like my coffee. Should I cut back, or quit totally? I know different things work for different guys, and I'm only at the beginning of my "journey", but I just want to get a feel for what may be working for you. It's only been 3 weeks since my surgery, but it feels like forever. Thanks for listening, and any input.

Posts.Title: Feedback about my potential surgeon

Posts.Content: When I first found out that I had PC, I, of course, first told friends and family, but then I told EVERYONE at work. (We have 20 employees) I was open about my diagnosis, treatment options, and on going "issues", so I have not really experienced people "stepping back". As time goes by, things have got back to "normal" at work, and now it's only occasionally that someone asks about it. I think being proactive, and openly discussing it yourself puts people at ease, let's them know you are approachable, and can show them that it's not a "taboo" subject. A bunch of friends even threw me a pre-surgery dinner a couple of days before my surgery. Great food, lot's of wine and beer..... but I was on a damn liquid diet prior to my surgery!!
Posts.Signature: Age 55 PSA 5.4 (Nov 2012) Prostate Biopsy Feb 22/13 11 cores taken 4 positive Gleason 3+3 retropubic Radical Prostatectomy April 23/13 Post Op Pathology Gleason 3+4 (7) involving 30% of prostate 29 gram, 4x3.9x3 cm 6 benign lymph nodes negative for metastatic malignancy Post op PSA <.01
Posts.Title: A replacement word for cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ChemoMan No need to say sorry While the bulk of our members are from the USA we have a sizable contingent of Australians and Brits. We also have New Zealander's and Europeans as well as people from various Asian counties posting here regularly. My apologies to any nationalities i have missed I see you have posted 11 times so my welcome is rather late in coming, but it is genuine none the less. All the best and as we say in Oz catcha ron. Don't forget little old Canada!

Posts.Title: A replacement word for cancer

Posts.Content: Quick question for those of you who had open retropubic Radical Prostatectomy surgery, and still work. How soon after surgery did you go back to work? Did you start back slowly, or right back full time? Today is 5 weeks since my surgery, and I went back to work for the first time, but just half a day. My energy level was good, just my incontinence bothered me. I work at a computer, but operate large printers so I'm up and down out of my seat quite often. Mark

Posts.Title: Back to work?

Posts.Content: Hi all. Haven't posted much lately, but thought I would today. It's hard to believe it's been one year today since I had my prostatectomy. Even if I haven't posted much I have kept track of all the new posts and responses, and I just want to thank you all for your support, direct or indirect. Also, all subsequent check ups and blood tests have been clear, so I think I can consider myself cancer free! Still dealing with a little stress incontinence, and ED is still part of my life, but it will come around too, I hope..... Thanks again everyone. Mark
Posts.Signature: Age 55 PSA 5.4 (Nov 2012) Prostate Biopsy Feb 22/13 11 cores taken 4 positive Gleason 3+3 retropubic Radical Prostatectomy April 23/13 Post Op Pathology Gleason 3+4 (7) involving 30% of prostate 29 gram, 4x3.9x3 cm 6 benign lymph nodes negative for metastatic malignancy Post op PSA <.01
Posts.Title: One year today....

Posts.Content: Hi all. Found this forum by accident today, searching for help with my bladder issues, so I registered right away! From what I have read so far, there are lots of knowledgeable, helpful, and sincere people here, and I look forward to "picking your brains" I do have a couple of questions, but I will save them for another post. I was "fortunate" enough to be diagnosed in early March of this year. I say fortunate because I found out through a series of events stemming from my father-in-laws "defective" blood pressure machine. He was having problems with it, and asked me to check it out, so I took my BP with it. It was HIGH! My wife freaked out, and needless to say insisted I get a check up. I deferred for a few weeks, but monitored my BP with a machine I have at home.(whole other story! ) I kept track on my iPhone and eventually made an appointment for a check up. Doc ordered blood tests, including PSA, which came back at 5.4 (a little high for my age, I'm 55) My doc then INSISTED that he do a rectal exam, which I have never had done. So I said, what the hell, I'm there, might as well do it before I think about it too much. Well, the doc felt that my prostate felt a "little abnormal" and referred me to a urologist, who examined me, and suggested a biopsy be done. Biopsy was done under general anesthetic, thank God. Biopsy came back positive for cancer, so doc recommended a Radical Prostatectomy, which was done retropubic on April 23/13. I was in hospital for 6 days, staples removed after 5 days. Went home with my friend the catheter, which was removed May 8th. Now sitting at home recovering. That's my story, hope it's not to long for you. Mark

Posts.Title: New to forum ....

Posts.Content: Hi all. Got back today from a little holiday on Vancouver Island, and the Okanagan area of British Columbia. Had a great time, however, about 4 days ago, I started to have trouble peeing. I really have to force it out, and it's just a trickle, not a good stream like it was previously. There is also some "discomfort" in my groin when I do pee. I am 10 weeks out of surgery, can scar tissue form that long after? I haven't called my doc yet, will do that first thing in the morning, just wanted to get some opinions from you guys. One "good" thing to come out of this, I am down to 1 pad a day from 4 or 5. Mark

Posts.Title: a little concerned...

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Fairwind Don't sit around at home very much...Get out and walk! You will heal faster and feel better for it.... I go for at least a couple of walks a day, one in the morning to go check the mail. I live in a town of 6000 people, so it's not a long walk to get to most places. Once my wife gets home from work we go for a walk before dinner. And you're right, we do feel better for it. I'm starting to do a few easy things in the yard too.

Right now I am using Depends Guards, and they work OK, but, from my experience, they tend to bunch up a little, which can lead to leaks. At work I'll usually go through 4-5 pads per day. Thanks

I just wear regular briefs right now. Off to Walmart! Mark

Posts.Title: a little concerned...

Posts.Content: Hi guys. Had my cystoscopy a short while ago, and it turns out the cause of my urinary restriction wasn't any of the mentioned reasons! It was caused by a couple of stitches from the surgery which hadn't dissolved and had irritated my urethra, causing a little swelling. Doc cut them out and said it should clear up in a few days. Have to wear a catheter 'til Monday just to keep the urethra open.

Posts.Content: OK. It's been almost a week using Tena, and, so far, I like them. Also bought some boxer briefs, great support, which helps with the comfort level. So, as of today, I think I prefer Tena over Depends. Hmm. Just read my post, and it got me thinking..... a couple of months ago I couldn't have imagined sitting here discussing the pro and cons of incontinence pads. Ain't life funny. Mark

Posts.Title: What's your preference?

Posts.Content: Hi. Just did a quick search of the Forum, and couldn't find an answer to my question, so I'll throw it out there for you guys (and girls). Since my surgery one year ago, I have had a couple of instances of diminished urine flow, basically a blocked urethra. One time I ended up in the ER with NO flow at all.... scary stuff. Anyway, my question is, and I realize how ambiguous it is, how long should it take to empty the average bladder, assuming it is full? I'm only asking because after the two episodes, I have tried to monitor my urine flow, and it seems such a long time since I peed without thinking my flow is slowing down, and I might just be a little paranoid about it. Anybody else having or had the same experience? Thanks for listening... Mark

Posts.Title: Urine flow...

Posts.Content: Now 14 weeks post op and things were progressing well, just a minor set back a few weeks ago, my urine flow was really poor and it turned out to be sutures that hadn't dissolved and were blocking the urethra. Doctor cut them out and things were fine 'til 2 days ago and my flow almost totally stopped! Went to emerg as pressure built, and of course they had to put a catheter in..... 3 attempts later, and 3 different sized catheters. no luck! That was fun . Luckily, my urologist was on call in the OR, so they got me in within an hour (a new world record?). Turns out there was some scarring, BUT, worst of all, some of the sutures were still there!! Doc used his fancy laser thing and vaporized everything, and I spent the night in hospital. Catheter stays in for a couple of days, then things should be back to normal.... I hope. Has anybody had a similar experience with indestructible sutures?

Posts.Title: Interesting (?) couple of days

Posts.Content: Removed catheter this morning and I can pee!!!! YAY! Incontinence is back a little worse again but hopefully will ease up.
Posts.Signature: Age 55 PSA 5.4 (Nov 2012) Prostate Biopsy Feb 22/13 11 cores taken 4 positive Gleason 3+3 retropubic Radical Prostatectomy April 23/13 Post Op Pathology Gleason 3+4 (7) involving 30% of prostate 29 gram, 4x3.9x3 cm 6 benign lymph nodes negative for metastatic malignancy Post op PSA <.01
Posts.Title: Interesting (?) couple of days

Posts.Content: Bit of a trivial question really, considering the prevailing subject of this forum, but I was wondering how soon after surgery you guys got to soak in the tub? I was told 4 weeks, which is tomorrow for me. What is the reason for this? I was allowed to shower as soon as I went home from the hospital, as long as I didn't rub the incision directly. Unfortunately I neglected to ask my doc why I couldn't bathe, and he's away until May 27th, so I have waited as instructed, though it's been hard. I enjoy the occasional soak in the tub. Just curious. Mark

Posts.Title: Bathing

Posts.Content: You've made all the tough decisions. Relax! BTW, the general anesthetic was so good, I barely remember the first day in the hospital! See you on the other side.

Posts.Title: 9 weeks out...

Posts.Content: 6 weeks out of surgery, and pretty much any movement makes me leak, unless I have sat for a while and my bladder fills, then I don't leak when I stand up or move around. I usually go through 4-6 pads at work.
